attributes.title: Influence of Unpredictable Context on Error Related Negativity
attributes.description:
The error related negativity (ERN) is a negative deflection typically appearing in centro-frontal regions after an error has been committed (Hajcak 2012). It is considered to reflect individual sensitivity to threat and to be modulated by unpredictable contexts. In this study we aim to replicate and expand previous data showing that the amplitude of the ERN is increased when unpredictable but not predictable tones occur in the background (Jackson et al., 2015). Participants will perform a Flanker task in four different conditions: during a predictable pattern of tones, during an unpredictable pattern of tones (replication part), during a predictable pattern of mildly painful cutaneous stimuli and during an unpredictable pattern of mildly painful cutaneous stimuli (expansion). The order of the stimuli will be counterbalanced across participants. High density (129 channels) EEG will be recorded. Participants will rate for each condition their anxiety, the un-/predictability, the unpleasantness and the intensity of the stimulus. In addition, participants will fill in the questionnaires - Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1984; Engelen, De Peuter, Victoir, Van Diest, & Van den Bergh, 2006), Anxiety Sensitivity Index (ASI, Deacon et al., 2004; Peterson & Heilbronner, 1987), Intolerance of Uncertainty (IoU) (Helsen, Van den Bussche, Vlaeyen, & Goubert, 2013), Life Orientation Test-Revised (Scheier et al. J Pers Soc Psychol. 1994), Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) (PCS, Sullivan, 1995), and Dyspnea Catastrophizing Scale (DCS). 
References:
Jackson F, Nelson B, Hajcak Proudfit G.  In an Uncertain World, Errors Are More Aversive: Evidence from the Error-Related Negativity. Emotion 2015; 15(1):12-16 
Hajcak, G. What we’ve learned from our mistakes: Insights from error-related brain activity. Current Directions in Psychological Science. 2012; 21:101–106.

q4.value:
Three main hypotheses will be tested:
Hypothesis 1 (Replication): Relative to predictable tones, unpredictable tones will increase sensitivity to potential threat—and thus potentiate the ERN (directional).
Hypothesis 2: Relative to predictable conditions, unpredictable conditions will increase the ERN in a comparable manner, whether the aversive contextual stimuli are acoustic or cutaneous (directional).
Hypothesis 3: The difference in the ERN between predictable and unpredictable conditions is higher for participants with higher intolerance of uncertainty and higher pain catastrophizing (directional).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a mixed design, with each participant performing a Flanker task in four different conditions: during a predictable pattern of tones, during an unpredictable pattern of tones, during a predictable pattern of mildly painful cutaneous stimuli and during an unpredictable pattern of mildly painful cutaneous stimuli. The order of the stimuli will be counterbalanced across participants, as well as the order of predictable and unpredictable trials. The task will consist of 8 blocks of 64 trials for each type of stimulus (1024 trials).

q9.value:
The participants will be pseudo-randomly distributed in four groups. The order of sensorial modalities - acoustic tone (A) or electrical stimulus (E) and the order of predictability (U/P) conditions (UPUP or PUPU) will differ as follow: Group A: APU-EPU; Group B: AUP-EUP; Group C: EPU-APU; Group D: EUP- AUP.
In the Flanker task, trials can be congruent or non-congruent; an equal number of congruent and non-congruent trials will be presented for each participant in each condition, in a randomized order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit volunteer healthy participants, aged between 18 and 40 years. They will be recruited via the Experiment Management System (EMS) at KU Leuven, via social media and via poster advertisements, and they will be reimbursed for their participation (1study credit/hour or 8EURO/hour). We aim at an equal gender distribution. We will exclude participants who meet one (or more) of the following self-reported criteria: previous participation in a Flanker study; cardiovascular or circulatory disease; respiratory disease; neurological disease; acute pain; chronic pain disorder (more than 3 months); pacemaker or other electronic medical implant; non-adjusted hearing and/or vision problems; psychiatric treatment; ongoing pain at the moment of testing; regular medication use (excluding contraceptives); pregnancy / breastfeeding; regular use of soft or hard drugs; sleep deprivation from the night before the experiment.

q13.value: Our target is 64 participants. However, time constraints might force us to limit the number of participants to 40, which represents a minimum.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect an effect size f(V) = .48 at the standard .05 alpha error probability in repeated measures ANOVAs.

q15.value: Our target is stopping the data collection at 64 participants. However, time constraints might force us to limit the number of participants to 40, which represents a minimum stopping rule.

question.value:
Predictability of the context: The contextual degree of predictability will be manipulated by providing predictable patterns of acoustical or electrical stimuli, versus unpredictable patterns of acoustical or electrical stimuli. The unpredictable sequence of stimuli will be generated from the predictable sequence by random temporal shift of each single stimulation. Predictable and unpredictable sequences will contain an identical number of stimuli and equivalent mean stimuli spacing. 
Level of unpleasantness of acoustic and electric stimuli: The perceptual threshold for the electrical stimulus will be established individually, in order to match the perceived unpleasantness of the original sound with an intensity of the electrical stimulus having a similar perceived unpleasantness. To this aim, the difference between “intensity” and “unpleasantness” will be explained to the participant. The tone used in the original study, delivered in a 5” predictable sequence, will be presented to the participant, who will rate it for unpleasantness, using a 7-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 = not unpleasant to 7 = extremely unpleasant. Like in the original study, the acoustic stimuli will be produced using a carrier frequency of 1 kHz with pulse duration of 40 ms and mean pulse spacing of 200 ms (5 Hz pulse repetition rate). The sequences will be played at 85 dB through external computer speakers positioned approximately 50 cm in front of the participant (Jackson et al., 2015). Next, through a bar electrode fixed to the posterior skin surface of the participant's wrist (from the non-dominant hand), the participant will receive an electrical stimulation at very low intensity (0.4mA) and will be asked to signal any sensation. They will receive additional increasing stimulations (in steps of 0.2mA), until they have a first sensation. After that, they will receive stimulation with the same intensity, until they can feel at least 5 out of 10 times. Predictable sequences of electrical stimuli, of 5” will be applied through a bar electrode to the posterior skin surface of the participant's wrist (from the non-dominant hand), using the intensity established in the previous step. Stimuli of a duration of 2ms each will be delivered with an inter-stimulus interval of 498ms. The participant will be asked to rate the unpleasantness, using a 7-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 = not unpleasant to 7 = extremely unpleasant. The intensity of electrical stimulation sequence will be increased with steps of 0.2mA, until the perceived unpleasantness will be the same as that for the acoustic stimuli. The determined intensity of electrical stimulus (in mA), having the same perceived unpleasantness as acoustic stimuli will be used in the test phase. 
Error-related behaviour: Participants’ errors are elicited using an Eriksen Flanker Task. This is a response inhibition test in which participants are requested to focus on a leftward or rightward pointing arrow presented centrally on a monitor while ignoring distracting flanking arrows pointing in the same or in the opposite direction. The task is to indicate the direction of the target / central arrow as quickly and as precisely as possible, by pressing the left/right mouse button. One trial consists of the presentation of 5 arrowheads for 200ms, followed by a response phase (1000ms) and a jittered inter-trial interval (mean: 800ms), which sums up to 2000ms per trial. There are two types of trials (congruent: <<<<< or >>>>> and non-congruent: <<><< or >><>>) – randomly determined, half from every type.

Behavioral measures: Number of errors; Reaction times
EEG measures: Error Related Negativity (ERN) amplitude; Correct Related Negativity (CRN) amplitude
Self-reported measures: Rated anxiety to predictable / unpredictable tone / electric stimuli, measured with a 7-point Likert scale from 1 to 7 (Not anxious - Extremely anxious); Rated unpleasantness after each condition, measured with a 7-point Likert scale from 1 to 7 (Not unpleasant – Extremely unpleasant); Rated predictability after each condition measured with a 7-point Likert scale from 1 to 7 (Predictable - Highly unpredictable); Rated intensity after each condition measured with a 7-point Likert scale from 1 to 7 (Low intensity – Extreme Intensity); Preferred Predictable / Unpredictable condition after each type of stimuli; Preferred Acoustic Unpredictable /Electric Unpredictable condition.
Questionnaires results: Intolerance of Uncertainty (IoU) (Helsen, Van den Bussche, Vlaeyen, & Goubert, 2013); Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS, Sullivan, 1995).

During each condition, 129‐channel EEG (Philips Electrical Geodesics Inc., Eugene, USA) will be continuously recorded using a sampling rate of 250 Hz. Impedance will be kept below 50 kΩ using Cz as reference. EEG data will be processed offline using Brain Electrical Source Analysis Research 6.0 (BESA GmbH, Gräfelfing, Germany). Data will be filtered between 0.1 and 30 Hz with an additional notch filter (50 Hz) added. An adaptive artifact correction (Ille, Berg, & Scherg, 2002) will be used, and data will be re-referenced to the original average reference. Response‐locked epochs with a duration of 1,500 ms, including a 500‐ms pre-response interval, will be extracted and averaged. The 500–300 ms pre-response interval will be used as the baseline. Blink artifacts will be corrected and additional artifacts (e.g., epochs with maximum amplitude >200 μV) will be removed. Noisy channels will be interpolated or, if necessary, removed (max. 12). Trials with response times below 200 ms and above 1,000 ms will not be analyzed. The ERN and CRN will be quantified as the mean amplitude between 0 and 100 ms after error (correct) response around the electrode FCz.
The ERN and CRN will both be calculated per subject by averaging the ERPs of all error-trials (minimally 6) and all correct-trials in the four different conditions, respectively. The same approach will be used to calculate the reaction times in the four different conditions. Accuracy will be computed as the percentage of correct trials in each of the conditions.

To verify the first hypothesis (replication analysis), we will analyse the results emerging from acoustic stimuli, only from the participants that underwent the acoustic type of stimulation first (as they are not biased by previous electric stimulation/ratings). 
I will present descriptive and inferential statistics for self-reported measures, ERN, CRN, and ΔERN (calculated by subtracting the CRN from the ERN). To compare predictable and unpredictable conditions, t-tests will be performed to check if there are significant differences between them for anxiety ratings, unpleasantness ratings, number of errors, mean error reaction time, and mean correct reaction time. A χ² test will be used to compare the percentages of the most disliked conditions (predictable and unpredictable).
The ERP data will be examined using a Response (Correct vs. Error) x Condition (Predictable Tones vs. Unpredictable Tones) repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA), testing for the main effect of Response and for Response x Condition interaction. 
Follow-up F-tests are planned for comparing the unpredictable versus predictable tones condition for ERN, as well as for comparing the unpredictable versus predictable tones condition for CRN.
Analysis of covariance will be performed as follow-up for Response x Condition interaction, controlling for the number of errors in predictable and unpredictable conditions.

For the second hypothesis, a multifactorial ANOVA will be performed for all subjects, in this design: 2 (response: correct vs. error) x 2 (condition: predictable vs. unpredictable) x 2 (stimulation mode: acoustic vs. electric), testing for the Response x Condition Interaction, for the main effect of Mode, and also for Response x Mode interaction and Response x Condition x Mode interaction. Follow-up F-tests are planned for comparing the ERN (CRN) and self-reported measures between unpredictable versus predictable conditions and between the stimulation modes.
In addition, if the analysis indicates no differences in ERN at the levels of Mode factor, additional Bayesian statistics will be used to determine the probability of Ho over H1.

The third hypothesis will be tested using multiple linear regression analysis, with the difference in ERN amplitude between predictable and unpredictable conditions as criterion, predicted by the scores for intolerance of uncertainty and pain catastrophizing. The criterion will be computed by averaging the ERN values obtained in acoustic and electric stimulation mode for each condition (predictable and unpredictable) and then subtracting them (U - P).

q21.value:
We will use the standard p < .05 criterion for determining if significant differences occurred between predictable and unpredictable conditions. The same standard p < .05 will be used to assess whether the measurements included in repeated measures ANOVA  (for the first hypothesis), multifactorial ANOVA (for the second hypothesis) and multiple linear regression (for the third hypothesis) are significantly different from those expected if the null hypotheses were correct. Effect sizes and confidence intervals for them will be computed, for each analysis. Moreover, the analysis will include corrections for multiple comparisons (B-Y method), (Benjamini & Yekutieli, 2001). We expect a positive Bayes factor (BF01 = 3 - 20) (Raftery 1995). 
References:
Benjamini & Yekutieli, 2001. Annals of Statistics, 29(4), 1165 – 1188. 
Raftery, Adrian E. 1995. “Bayesian Model Selection in Social Research.” Sociological Methodology 25: 111–64.

q22.value:
The responses that do not fall within the given response time window (200 - 1000ms) will not be considered in the analysis.
We will exclude participants with fewer than six errors per condition. 
We will exclude participants who don’t rate the (original) tone as unpleasant, because we cannot match an equivalent unpleasantness of the electrical stimuli for them.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete the Flanker Tasks or does not respond to all self-report scales, that participant will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: Scores in the questionnaires Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS), Anxiety Sensitivity Index (ASI), Life Orientation Test-Revised (LoT-R), and Dyspnea Catastrophizing Scale (DCS) will only be used in explorative analyses.

attributes.title: Children's Image Presence Improves Hand Hygiene Compliance : A Study on the Role Model Effect of Children's Attention

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value:
Children's Image Presence Improves Hand Hygiene Compliance ¬¬: A Study on the Role Model Effect of Children's Attention
This study was conducted in four treatment rooms in the hospital, which were divided into two departments: obstetrics and gynecology and neonatology. The research assistant changed the sticker during the shift and recorded the exact time the sticker was changed. Researchers regularly check to make sure the stickers are not damaged and that the visual primers are working properly. Visual priming consists of four conditions: blank, flower, adult eyes and children's eyes. Each sticker lasts at least a week in the department. Each hand-washing instance was coded as "hand washing" or "not washing"." Hand hygiene" is defined as the use of hand sanitizer. The hypothesis was verified by coding each hand-washing behavior

attributes.title: The Influence of Emotional Labels on Racial Biases in Face Perception among Children

q1.value: Effects of Primary vs. Secondary Emotion Labels on Racial Biases in Face Perception Among Children

q3.value: Both children and adults are better at recognizing faces from their own social groups (Meissner & Brigham, 2001), but emphasizing ingroup status reduces group-based biases in face perception (Young & Hugenberg, 2010). Additionally, ingroup members are associated with uniquely human "secondary" emotions (e.g., pride, compassion, regret), while outgroup members are associated with animalistic "primary" emotions (e.g., anger, fear, joy) (Leyens et al, 2000). Given this evidence, we are investigating whether racial biases in face recognition exhibited by children can be mitigated by attributing secondary emotions to members of an outgroup.

q4.value:
1. Children will demonstrate a deficit in facial recognition for black faces compared to white faces. 
2. This deficit will be reduced among black faces that are described with secondary (compared to primary) emotion labels. 
3. The effect described in #2 gradually develops over the course of development, such that it is stronger for older children than younger children.
4. The use of primary vs. secondary emotion labels will have no effect on children's recognition of white faces.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study utilizes a repeated measures design with 3 factors (race, gender, emotion label), each with two levels (black, white; male, female; primary, secondary). 

Participants will view eight short videos displaying faces of neutral expression (2 black males, 2 black females, 2 white males, 2 white females), each describing a distinct scenario and the target’s resulting emotions. The eight distinct scenarios are counterbalanced, such that each scenario is attached to a black male face, a black female face, a white male face, or a white female face. Each of these four pairings is presented with either primary (happy/sad) or secondary (proud/jealous) emotion labels, thus resulting in eight versions of the study. 

For each study version, half of the videos describe the target using primary emotion labels (happy/sad), and the other half describe the target using secondary emotion labels (proud/jealous). Emotion label is counterbalanced, such that half of the participants will see the same four faces (1 black male, 1 black female, 1 white male, 1 white female) described with primary emotion labels, while the remaining participants will see these same four faces described with secondary emotion labels (and vice versa for the other four faces). 

After viewing each video, participants will be presented with a single pair of images of the target’s face, including the original image next to one that varies slightly in facial morphology. They will be asked to identify which face they have just seen by pressing one of two keys on a laptop keyboard. The positioning of the original face (left or right side of the screen) will alternate across all eight trials and is counterbalanced across participants, such that half of the participants will see the same four faces on the left side of the screen, while the remaining participants will these same four faces on the right side of the screen (and vice versa for the other four faces). 

For each study version, the stimuli are arranged across two distinct blocks: primary and secondary. Within each block, the four faces described with either primary or secondary labels are presented in randomized order. The order of the two blocks is also randomized.

Before beginning the eight test trials, each participant will be led through a practice trial.

The study will be run using the software program Testable, which will record accuracy and reaction time for each trial.

q9.value: We will randomly assign each participant to one of the eight equally sized versions of the study. The random number list will be generated at https://www.graphpad.com/quickcalcs/randomize2/.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited by establishing partnerships with local schools and museums. Participating schools and museums will receive $5 worth of toys/supplies per participating child. Participants must be between 5 and 12 years of age and have normal (or corrected to normal) vision and hearing.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants (50 aged 5-8 years and 50 aged 9-12 years). We will attempt to recruit up to 120, assuming that not all participants will complete the study as directed.

question.value: We manipulated race (black vs. white), gender (male vs. female), and emotion label (primary vs. secondary) across the eight facial stimuli used in this study.

The single outcome variable will be reaction time (in milliseconds) for each trial. The binary variable of accuracy will also be collected, as only reaction time for correct responses will be analyzed.

To analyze our results, we will use a 2 x 2 x 2 repeated measures ANOVA with all factors (race, gender, emotion label) within subjects, and reaction time as our DV. We will analyze the main effect of race, and the interaction of race and emotion label. We will further investigate how this interaction varies across gender of facial stimuli.

We will run this analysis on the data as a whole, and then again within each age group (5-8, 9-12), running contrast analyses between the two groups.

q21.value: We will set a p value of .05 as our alpha criterion.

q22.value: We will only exclude data from participants who are visibly distracted during the study (e.g., talking to the experimenter across trials, looking away from the videos as they play on screen, etc.) or who express that they didn't understand the task. Reaction time outliers that do not fall into the above categories will be retained.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete all eight trials of the study, their data will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value: We will explore the effect of (stimulus) gender on facial recognition, with no expectations about how it will influence reaction time across trials or interact with race and emotion label.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of Pan-Ethnic and National Origin Identity Appeals on Latino and Asian American Voters

q1.value: Effectiveness of Pan-Ethnic and National Origin Identity Appeals on Latino and Asian American Voters

q3.value: This project seeks to understand the relative effectiveness of pan-ethnic and national origin appeals on Asian American vote choice. Previous scholarship have found that pan-ethnic identities is positively associated with higher rates of mobilization and turnout among non-black voters, mainly Latinos and Asian Americans. However, members of these groups prefer their national origin identities. This project seeks to understand whether and for whom pan-ethnic identity appeals will be effective for political incorporation of these groups.

q4.value:
H1: Asian American respondents in the sample will be indifferent to the candidate appealing to their pan-ethnic identity. (no statistically significant  effect of the “Asian American” appeal on candidate vote choice). The coefficient for pan-ethnic appeal will be indistinguishable different from the “American” control condition. (main treatment effect)

H2: foreign-born Asian American respondents in the sample will be more responsive to the national origin appeal. The coefficient for national origin appeal will be positive and statistically significant from the “American” control condition.  (interaction effect: treatments * nativity status)

H3: U.S.-born Asian American respondents in the sample will be more responsive to the pan-ethnic appeal. The coefficient for pan-ethnic appeal will be positive and statistically significant from the “American” control condition. (interaction effect: treatments * nativity status)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: See attachment for detailed experimental conditions.

q9.value:
There will be total of N=1050 respondents.

A random 1/3 of the respondents will be assigned to the pan-ethnic treatment condition.
A random 1/3 of the respondents will be assigned to the national origin treatment condition.
A random 1/3 of the respondents will be assigned to the American control condition.

Bloc randomization will happen through the Qualtrics survey tool.

18+ Asian Americans who reside in the United States with a minimal N of 1,050 and with enough collaborators, growing it to 1500. Half of the sample will be foreign-born Asian Americans. I'm aiming for it to be as nicely split between the top 5 national-origin groups as possible. 

The respondents will be recruited through Bovitz.

q13.value: N=1050 completes. But up to N=1200 will be collected in order to get to N=1050 completes.

q15.value: I will stop collecting the data once I reach my N=1050 limit.

attributes.title: Mortality Salience, PTSD Symptomology and Disgust Sensitivity

q1.value: Mortality Salience, PTSD Symptomology, and Disgust Sensitivity

q3.value: This study aims to assess the ability of Mortality Salience and PTSD symptoms to uniquely predict changes in disgust sensitivity in college undergraduate students. Evidence suggests that Mortality Salience may increase disgust sensitivity. Furthermore, past research indicates that individuals who are experiencing PTSD symptoms may be more prone to disgust after being exposed to disgust provoking stimuli. Given the relationship between death and disgust, we reasoned that individuals who are experiencing PTSD symptoms may be even more prone to experiencing disgust following exposure to disgust provoking stimuli after they have been exposed to a mortality salience prime.

q4.value:
1.	Participants that are exposed to a mortality salience task (prime) will report being more disgusted by disgust provoking stimuli than individuals who are exposed to a dental pain control task.
2.	Participants that are experiencing trauma symptoms will report being more disgusted by disgust provoking stimuli than individuals who are not experiencing PTSD symptoms.
3.	Participants that are experiencing PTSD symptoms and who are exposed to a mortality salience task (prime) will show a greater increase in disgust in response to mortality salience than those without PTSD symptoms; that is PTSD will moderate the effect of mortality salience.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subjects design with one manipulated independent variable (mortality Salience) and two levels (Mortality Salience task or Dental Pain control task). Simple random assignment of participants to the conditions. PTSD symptomology is a participant variable in that participants will report the extent to which they are experiencing trauma related symptoms and this will be treated as a continuous variable in our analyses.

q9.value: Using simple random assignment, participants will be randomly assigned to either the Mortality Salience condition (Mortality Salience task) or the control condition (Dental Pain control task). Participants will be randomized using the randomizer tool in the Qualtrics data collection platform. Qualtrics will assign a total of 100 participants to the Mortality Salience Condition and another 100 participants to the Dental Pain Control condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data in this study have already been collected by the researchers in a lab setting prior to preregistration of the study. In order to assure that researchers are unaware of any patterns or summary statistics in the data, the dataset has only been exported from the Qualtrics data collection site and formatted as a SPSS file. No analyses have been conducted to explore any descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, hypothesis testing, or exploratory analyses. Access to the dataset has been restricted to the PI, Ben Graf, others involved in the study have no current access to the dataset.

question.value: All participants in the study consisted of undergraduate students enrolled at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs (UCCS). There were no inclusionary or exclusionary criteria utilized to recruit participants for this study. Participants were recruited using the UCCS participant recruitment program, SONA. The UCCS SONA system places out a sign up sheet that interested participants can use to register for a time slot in the lab. Additionally, there were emails that were sent out from the SONA system administrator advertising open recruitment for the study. Participants were compensated with 2 SONA points which can be applied to undergraduate psychology courses for extra class credit. Data were collected from August 2019 through December 2019 and ended once the 200 participant recruitment goal was met.

q13.value: A total of 200 participants engaged in the study.

q14.value: A standard 200 participants was used to have sufficient power to conduct a regression analysis.

q15.value: Data collection stopped as soon as researchers had collected data on 200 participants. Following this threshold, no more participants were able to sign up for the study and all scheduled time-slots were cancelled. Participants that were signed up for participation past the 200 threshold were given compensation and their time-slots were cancelled.

question.value: The only variable that was manipulated in this study was Mortality Salience. Participants were randomly assigned to a Mortality Salience task or a Dental Pain Control task. The Mortality Salience task asked participants about their thoughts on death, while the Dental Pain Control task asked participants about their thoughts on going to the dentist.

PTSD Symptoms: Measured as a predictor variable using the PCL-5 self-report inventory. Higher endorsement rates on each item on the PCL indicates higher frequency and severity of trauma symptoms. In no way was the PCL used for any diagnostic purposes and participants were unaware of their score on this measure. 
Disgust Sensitivity: Measured as an outcome variable using the Disgust Scale Revised (DS – R). The disgust sensitivity scale presents various situations in which the participant experiences something obscure and disgust provoking. Participants rate on a Likert scale the extent to which they would find the specific situation presented to be disgusting.
Neuroticism: Measured using the Big 5 Neuroticism Scale. Neuroticism is measured for potential exploratory analyses. The higher a participant rates the items on the scale, the higher presence of neuroticism.
Mortality Salience: Mortality Salience is also measured for exploratory purposes. The more a participant answers “true” to death fear items, the higher their fear of death is measured.
N/A

Because PTSD was measured at the end of the study, to avoid activating emotions that might affect the results, we will first perform a t-test to determine if Mortality Salience affected reported PTSD symptomology. If there mortality salience has no effect on reported PTSD symptoms, this justifies using this measure as a predictor in the regression model.
A multiple regression will be conducted to see if Mortality Salience condition and PTSD symptoms, along with their interaction, uniquely predict variance in self-reported disgust sensitivity. If a significant interaction is found, we will probe the interaction with tests for simple main effects of mortality salience at high, medium, and low levels of PTSD and tests for simple slopes of PTSD predicting disgust sensitivity in the mortality salience and control conditions.

q20.value:
A detailed coding scheme is required for all categorical variables, additionally reverse scoring is needed on several measures in the study. The Big 5 neuroticism scale requires reverse scoring of the 1-5 Likert scale on items 2 and 4. The ACH - S Failure subscale requires reverse scoring on the dichotomous response questions: 3,4,7,12. The Dental Pain task requires reverse scoring on the dichotomous response questions: 3,4,7,6,8, and 10. The Mortality Salience task requires reverse scoring on the dichotomous response questions: 2,3,5,6,7, and 15. The Disgust Scale revised requires reverse scoring on the 0-4 Likert scale on items 1,4,10, and 12.
A total disgust sensitivity composite will be calculated by adding together all of the response values from each item on the disgust scale revised.
A total mortality salience composite will be calculated by adding together all of the response values from each item on the mortality salience task. This will be completed for both time one and time two.
A total Neuroticism composite will be calculated by adding together all of the response values from each item on the Big 5 Neuroticism scale.
A total Trauma Symptom composite will be calculated by adding together all of the response values from each item on the PCL – 5. 
A total dental pain composite will be calculated by adding together all of the respone values from each item on the Dental Pain Control task. This will be completed for both time one and time two. 
Demographic (categorical) variables will need to be coded in the data set. Gender will be coded where cisgender male = 1, cisgender female = 2, transgender male = 3, transgender female = 4, Non-binary/gender fulid = 5, and other = 6.

registration_responses.q1: Mortality Salience, PTSD Symptomology, and Disgust Sensitivity
registration_responses.q3: This study aims to assess the ability of Mortality Salience and PTSD symptoms to uniquely predict changes in disgust sensitivity in college undergraduate students. Evidence suggests that Mortality Salience may increase disgust sensitivity. Furthermore, past research indicates that individuals who are experiencing PTSD symptoms may be more prone to disgust after being exposed to disgust provoking stimuli. Given the relationship between death and disgust, we reasoned that individuals who are experiencing PTSD symptoms may be even more prone to experiencing disgust following exposure to disgust provoking stimuli after they have been exposed to a mortality salience prime.
registration_responses.q4:
1.	Participants that are exposed to a mortality salience task (prime) will report being more disgusted by disgust provoking stimuli than individuals who are exposed to a dental pain control task.
2.	Participants that are experiencing trauma symptoms will report being more disgusted by disgust provoking stimuli than individuals who are not experiencing PTSD symptoms.
3.	Participants that are experiencing PTSD symptoms and who are exposed to a mortality salience task (prime) will show a greater increase in disgust in response to mortality salience than those without PTSD symptoms; that is PTSD will moderate the effect of mortality salience.

registration_responses.q8.question: Between subjects design with one manipulated independent variable (mortality Salience) and two levels (Mortality Salience task or Dental Pain control task). Simple random assignment of participants to the conditions. PTSD symptomology is a participant variable in that participants will report the extent to which they are experiencing trauma related symptoms and this will be treated as a continuous variable in our analyses.
registration_responses.q12.question: All participants in the study consisted of undergraduate students enrolled at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs (UCCS). There were no inclusionary or exclusionary criteria utilized to recruit participants for this study. Participants were recruited using the UCCS participant recruitment program, SONA. The UCCS SONA system places out a sign up sheet that interested participants can use to register for a time slot in the lab. Additionally, there were emails that were sent out from the SONA system administrator advertising open recruitment for the study. Participants were compensated with 2 SONA points which can be applied to undergraduate psychology courses for extra class credit. Data were collected from August 2019 through December 2019 and ended once the 200 participant recruitment goal was met.
registration_responses.q16.question: The only variable that was manipulated in this study was Mortality Salience. Participants were randomly assigned to a Mortality Salience task or a Dental Pain Control task. The Mortality Salience task asked participants about their thoughts on death, while the Dental Pain Control task asked participants about their thoughts on going to the dentist.
registration_responses.q17.question:
PTSD Symptoms: Measured as a predictor variable using the PCL-5 self-report inventory. Higher endorsement rates on each item on the PCL indicates higher frequency and severity of trauma symptoms. In no way was the PCL used for any diagnostic purposes and participants were unaware of their score on this measure. 
Disgust Sensitivity: Measured as an outcome variable using the Disgust Scale Revised (DS – R). The disgust sensitivity scale presents various situations in which the participant experiences something obscure and disgust provoking. Participants rate on a Likert scale the extent to which they would find the specific situation presented to be disgusting.
Neuroticism: Measured using the Big 5 Neuroticism Scale. Neuroticism is measured for potential exploratory analyses. The higher a participant rates the items on the scale, the higher presence of neuroticism.
Mortality Salience: Mortality Salience is also measured for exploratory purposes. The more a participant answers “true” to death fear items, the higher their fear of death is measured.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
Because PTSD was measured at the end of the study, to avoid activating emotions that might affect the results, we will first perform a t-test to determine if Mortality Salience affected reported PTSD symptomology. If there mortality salience has no effect on reported PTSD symptoms, this justifies using this measure as a predictor in the regression model.
A multiple regression will be conducted to see if Mortality Salience condition and PTSD symptoms, along with their interaction, uniquely predict variance in self-reported disgust sensitivity. If a significant interaction is found, we will probe the interaction with tests for simple main effects of mortality salience at high, medium, and low levels of PTSD and tests for simple slopes of PTSD predicting disgust sensitivity in the mortality salience and control conditions.

attributes.title: Refining the maturity principle of personality development using facets and informants
Predicting Changes In Public Opinion With Twitter: What Social Media Data Can And Can't Tell Us About Opinion Formation

q1.value: Predicting Changes In Public Opinion With Twitter: What Social Media Data Can And Can't Tell Us About Opinion Formation

q3.value: This study analyzes time lags and potential correlations between public opinion polling, Twitter bot sentiment, and Twitter sentiment when those bots are removed. The study is designed to explore whether it is plausible that opinion leaders turn to Twitter to settle on their perspectives among one another before disseminating those views to the public. Previous research suggests changes in social media sentiment predict changes in public opinion research. This study includes a data exploration designed to detect this phenomenon as well as to determine which lag time found in previous research, if any, is most predictive. Lastly, it applies bot detection software and sentiment analysis to discover Twitter accounts likely to be fully automated, known as bots, and to explore whether changes in bot sentiment are predictive of changes in Twitter sentiment when those bots are removed, proposing a new way to explore the possibility of societal influence by social media bots.

q4.value:
This study’s hypotheses explore correlations between public polling data, Twitter bot sentiment, and Twitter sentiment when those bots are removed within two separate conversations: the economy and the president. The topics were selected because previous research has explored them and to discover any possible differences in the two. Since the paper’s theoretical foundation expects the same result across both topics, the hypotheses are likewise identical for both topics.

This study measures its hypotheses in two ways: individual-based sentiment and conversation-based sentiment. Conversation-based sentiment is measured by taking the average sentiment of every tweet in a corpus, whereas individual-based sentiment is measured by taking the average sentiment of every user’s tweets combined in a corpus. Prevailing methods in the field of social media data usability in public opinion research has relied on conversation-based sentiment (Ceron et al., 2014; Fu & Chan, 2013; O’Connor et al., 2010) while perhaps only one has used individual-based sentiment measurement (Barberra, 2016).

-Hypothesis 1: Changes in the sentiment of social media users on a given topic are predictive of changes in public polling support on the same topic.
--Hypothesis 1a: Changes in conversation-based sentiment measurement, rather than that of individual-based measurement, will more closely predict changes in public polling.
--Hypothesis 1b: Removing verified users from individual-based sentiment measurement will not significantly alter the study’s results.

-Hypothesis 2: Changes in the sentiment of Twitter bots on a given topic are predictive of changes in the sentiment of Twitter sentiment when those bots are removed on the same topic.
--Hypothesis 2a: Changes in conversation-based sentiment measurement, rather than that of individual-based measurement, will more closely predict changes in Twitter sentiment when those bots are removed.
--Hypothesis 2b: Removing verified users from individual-based sentiment measurement will not significantly alter the study’s results.

While pre-processing of the Twitter posts has begun, as analyzing each corpus for bot activity is a time-intensive task, no statistical methods have been applied to the data to compare any sets of data and polling results have not yet been collected. Data pre-processing will continue but analysis will only begin once all data collection is complete.

question.value:
-Tweets
Tweets for each day of a 44-day span are collected via Twitter’s streaming API at a random time determined by random at midnight of each day. Two data sets are built, to include all tweets containing the term “Trump” and tweets related to the economy. Two thousand tweets from each topic for each day will be isolated for analysis.

-Polling Data
Using daily polling results from Rasmussen, public opinion as measured by random sample surveys will be recorded over a 44-day span.

q13.value: Each day’s sample is 2000 tweets related either to the president or the economy. Analysis will require rolling averages of three days for each topic.

q14.value: In previous research, 2000 tweets was found to be the best compromise of data set size and processing time in order to maximize the accuracy of bot detection software.

question.value:
Polling Data

-Presidential Approval
--How would you rate the job Donald Trump has been doing as president…do you strongly approve, somewhat approve, somewhat disapprove, or strongly disapprove of the job he’s been doing?

Twitter Data

-Bot Likelihood Score 
--Whether a Twitter account is likely to be a bot will be recorded using BotOMeter (https://github.com/IUNetSci/botometer-python). Any accounts registering over 0.43 in the CAP variable (Completely Automated Probability) will be considered a bot for this study. CAP is rates each account on a 0-1.0 scale.
-Twitter Data With Bots Removed
-Sentiment
--Removing identified bots, the sentiment of each day’s remaining corpus for each topic will be analyzed via sentimentR (https://github.com/trinker/sentimentr). This software rates sentence sentiment on a -1.0-+1.0 scale.
-Verified Status
-Twitter Bot Sentiment
--The sentiment of each day’s bot-authored corpus for each topic will be analyzed using sentimentR.

Polling Data

-Consumer Confidence Index
--This index is calculated by Rasmussen using responses on five questions. The results are available as an average of three days at a time, known as rolling averages.
---Generally speaking, how would you rate the U.S. economy these days? Excellent, good, fair, or poor?
---Are economic conditions in the country getting better or worse?
---How would you rate your own personal finances these days?
---Are your personal finances getting better these days, or worse?
---Is the United States currently in a recession?

Twitter Data

-Twitter Sentiment
--To compare as closely as possible to polling data, social media sentiment data will be measured in three-day rolling averages.
--Corpus
---The sentimentR package provides sentiment scores by sentence. These scores are then combined with any other sentences in each tweet to produce an average sentiment score per tweet. The average sentiment score for all tweets will be considered the day’s corpus-based sentiment score.
--Individual
---Rather than averaging all of a day’s tweets, individual-based measurement will first include combining all of a user’s tweets and average all user-based averages.

registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: The data are in the midst of being collected. Posts from Twitter and public polling results will be collected for this study. While pre-processing of the Twitter posts has begun, as analyzing each corpus for bot activity is a time-intensive task, no statistical methods have been applied to the data to compare any sets of data and polling results have not yet been collected. Data pre-processing will continue but analysis will only begin once all data collection is complete.
registration_responses.q13: Each day’s sample is 2000 tweets related either to the president or the economy. Analysis will require rolling averages of three days for each topic.
registration_responses.q14: In previous research, 2000 tweets was found to be the best compromise of data set size and processing time in order to maximize the accuracy of bot detection software.
registration_responses.q21: I will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the multiple linear regression tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The adjusted R2 (Yin & Fan. 2001)  will point to the size of the effect in each hypothesis.
registration_responses.q22: No checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion. Outliers will be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a longitudinal observation study.
registration_responses.q12.question:
-Tweets
Tweets for each day of a 44-day span are collected via Twitter’s streaming API at a random time determined by random at midnight of each day. Two data sets are built, to include all tweets containing the term “Trump” and tweets related to the economy. Two thousand tweets from each topic for each day will be isolated for analysis.

-Polling Data
Using daily polling results from Rasmussen, public opinion as measured by random sample surveys will be recorded over a 44-day span.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Polling Data

-Presidential Approval
--How would you rate the job Donald Trump has been doing as president…do you strongly approve, somewhat approve, somewhat disapprove, or strongly disapprove of the job he’s been doing?

Twitter Data

-Bot Likelihood Score 
--Whether a Twitter account is likely to be a bot will be recorded using BotOMeter (https://github.com/IUNetSci/botometer-python). Any accounts registering over 0.43 in the CAP variable (Completely Automated Probability) will be considered a bot for this study. CAP is rates each account on a 0-1.0 scale.
-Twitter Data With Bots Removed
-Sentiment
--Removing identified bots, the sentiment of each day’s remaining corpus for each topic will be analyzed via sentimentR (https://github.com/trinker/sentimentr). This software rates sentence sentiment on a -1.0-+1.0 scale.
-Verified Status
-Twitter Bot Sentiment
--The sentiment of each day’s bot-authored corpus for each topic will be analyzed using sentimentR.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Polling Data

-Consumer Confidence Index
--This index is calculated by Rasmussen using responses on five questions. The results are available as an average of three days at a time, known as rolling averages.
---Generally speaking, how would you rate the U.S. economy these days? Excellent, good, fair, or poor?
---Are economic conditions in the country getting better or worse?
---How would you rate your own personal finances these days?
---Are your personal finances getting better these days, or worse?
---Is the United States currently in a recession?

Twitter Data

-Twitter Sentiment
--To compare as closely as possible to polling data, social media sentiment data will be measured in three-day rolling averages.
--Corpus
---The sentimentR package provides sentiment scores by sentence. These scores are then combined with any other sentences in each tweet to produce an average sentiment score per tweet. The average sentiment score for all tweets will be considered the day’s corpus-based sentiment score.
--Individual
---Rather than averaging all of a day’s tweets, individual-based measurement will first include combining all of a user’s tweets and average all user-based averages.
